Lab 1B : BLUETOOTH

Prelab

For the Prelab for 1B, I had to install both Python 3 and pip. I had to make sure that I had the latest releases of both Python and pip afterwords (just to be sure!). I then had to create the A virtual environment and installed Python Packages. I proceeded to download and unzip the codebase into my project directory. Finally, I started the Jupyter server and read through processing commands on the Artemis board.

Configuration: By following the configuration instructions, I was able to update the Artemis MAC Address on my Computer. As shown below:

I also was able to generate a new UUID and then replaced BLEService UUID with the generated UUID. As shown below:

Results in the Python side:

In task 1, I had to program the Artemis to echo back the data that was sent to it. The a Artemis board sent back to the computer a string. The string was then printed out in the Python terminal after receiving the string.

Task 2 : SEND_THREE_FLOATS

Code in the Arduino side:

In the Python side:

In task 2, I had to program the SEND_THREE_FLOATS command to send three floats from the computer to the artemis board. I followed the format of that of SEND_TWO_INTS which allowed me to send three floats to the Artemis board to then be printed in the serial monitor.

Task 3 : GET_TIME_MILLIS

Code in the Arduino side:

Results in the Python side:

Before I can begin task 3, I had to declare the command in the command types and in ble.arduino.ino. Once I had that setup in the Arduino side, I did a string that would have "T:", representing time, and then the time in milliseconds (used the built in function). I realize now that I should have added the units of time. Even so, in the Python side, I was able to print out string that was sent from the Artemis board.

Task 4 : Notification Handler

Notifcation Handler was successful given it was able to print out the string for time without using ble.receive_string(ble.uuid['RX_STRING']) to recieve the string. As shown below:

For the notifcation handler, I essentially printed out the strings, and the when you ran any command (send the command), it would print out the string without having to run the ble.receive_string(ble.uuid['RX_STRING']) command.

Task 5 : GET_TIME_MILLIS

Code in the Arduino side:

Results in the Python side:

In task 5, I created a new command called TIME_LOOP. This command essentially had a start time which would be stored. In the while loop, it would send a string to the computer of the number of counts and the time in milliseconds for 5 secs. Once we had the recieved the string, we can then calculate the effective data transfer rate. My math: Each timestep is a int and therefore each is 2 bytes. since there are 128 data points => 128*2 = 256 bytes number of seconds elapsed is 5 secs => that 256 bytes/5 secs = 51.2 bytes/sec

Task 6 : SEND_TIME_DATA

Code in the Arduino side:

Results in the Python side:

In task 6, I had to create a new command called SEND_TIME_DATA. I set the time_array to only have 20 elements. In the ble.arduino side, I frist set a for loop which would go through 20 elements, and element of the time_array time would be stored in the time_array. The time_array would then be sent to the computer through a for loop which would go each element and string it.

Task 7 : GET_TEMP_READINGS

Code in the Arduino side:

Results in the Python side:

I implemented the same logic as in task 6, but instead of just storing time, I also stored the temperature readings. I created a temp array that is the same size as time_array. I would then string the time and the temperature to be sent to the computer.

Task 8 : Discussion

In the frist method, the disadvange was that it only sent one message to the computer, and it was very quick to send the message to the computer (did it in less than a second). In the second method, the advantage was that you were able to into two arrays and then send the values of the arrays to the computer. The disadvange was that it was not as quick as the frist method, the time elasdped was 9secs. Please keep in mind in both methods, the arrays were of the same size. Another advantage is that since it is slower, it may be able to get accurate data, but you will not be able to anaylze the data in real-time. The second method has a data transfer rate of ... Each timestep is a float and therefore each is 4 bytes. since there are 128 data points => 20*4 = 80 bytes number of seconds elapsed is 9 secs => that 80 bytes/9 secs = 8.9 bytes/sec Considering that the Artemis board has 384kB of RAM and a float is 4 bytes, the maximum number of floats that can be stored is 96,000. If we consdier the second method, the time_array and temp_array,each 4 bytes, the maximum number of floats that can be stored is 48,000.

Task 6 : Effective Data Rate And Overhead

Code in the Arduino side:

Results in the Python side:

In task 5, I created a new command called TIME_LOOP. This command essentially had a start time which would be stored. In the while loop, it would send a string to the computer of the number of counts and the time in milliseconds for 5 secs. Once we had the recieved the string, we can then calculate the effective data transfer rate. My math: Each timestep is a int and therefore each is 2 bytes. since there are 128 data points => 128*2 = 256 bytes number of seconds elapsed is 5 secs => that 256 bytes/5 secs = 51.2 bytes/sec
